technical-data.invention-title: Klebefilm, Klebstoffzusammensetzung dafür und optisches Element damit
Adhesive film, adhesive composition for the same and optical member including the same
Film adhésif, sa composition adhésive et élément optique comprenant celui-ci

abstract.p: An adhesive film, an adhesive composition for the same, and an optical member including the same are disclosed. The adhesive composition includes a (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate groups and an aromatic groups. The adhesive film can be used to attach transparent members to each other, inhibit variation in capacitance, prevent malfunction due to touching, and improve outdoor visibility in a capacitive touch panel.

An adhesive film, an adhesive composition for the same, and an optical member including the same are disclosed. The adhesive composition includes a (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate groups and an aromatic groups. The adhesive film can be used to attach transparent members to each other, inhibit variation in capacitance, prevent malfunction due to touching, and improve outdoor visibility in a capacitive touch panel.

description.heading: Field of the Invention
description.p: The present invention relates to an adhesive film, an adhesive composition for the same, and an optical member including the same. More particularly, the present invention relates to an adhesive film, which can be used to attach transparent members to each other, inhibit variation in capacitance, prevent malfunction due to touching, and improve outdoor readability in a capacitive touch panel, an adhesive composition for the same, and an optical member including the same.
description.heading: Description of the Related Art
description.p: A capacitive touchpad is bonded to a window or film via a transparent adhesive. The capacitive touchpad detects variation in capacitance of the window or the film. As human hands or predetermined materials (conductors or liquids) are in proximity with or contact a unipolar detecting plate, dielectric constant of the unipolar detecting plate is varied. In accordance with such dielectric constant variation of the unipolar detecting plate, capacitance is varied to generate a switching signal.

In capacitive touch panels employing typical adhesive films, the capacitance is varied due to dielectric constant variation of the adhesive film, thereby causing switch signal malfunction. Specifically, such malfunction may be more severe when dielectric constant variation of the adhesive film is large. In addition, malfunctions can occur when the switch signal is greatly changed due to external noise in a display of the touch panel.

In this context, Japanese Patent Publication No. 2012-041456A discloses an acrylic polymer compound, which is copolymerized from monomer components including (a) a (meth)acrylic ester monomer containing a C1-C12 hydrocarbon group, (b) a (meth)acrylic ester monomer containing a hydroxyl group, (c) a monomer having an amide group and (d) a vinyl ester monomer, and is employed in an resin-based adhesive composition for a touch panel having an acid value of ≤ 0.1 mg KOH/g and a dielectric constant of ≥ 3 to ≤ 6.
description.heading: Summary of the Invention
description.p:
In one embodiment, the present invention provides an adhesive film having an index of refraction of ≥ 1.48 and a dielectric constant variation of ≤ 30% as expressed by Equation 1: Dielectric constant variation%=A-BA⁢X100,
wherein A is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz, and B is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 106 Hz.

In another embodiment, the present invention provides an adhesive film having an average dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0 at 103Hz to 106 Hz and a resistance variation (△R) of ≤ 2%, as expressed by Equations 2 and 3, respectively: Average Dielectric constant=Emax+Emin2,
wherein Emax is a maximum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz, and Emin is a minimum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz, ΔR=P2-P1P1X100,
wherein P1 is an initial resistance (unit: Ω) measured on a sample with electrodes formed at both ends of the adhesive film, and P2 is resistance (unit: Ω) of the sample after storage at 60°C/90% RH for 240 hours.
In another embodiment, the present invention provides an adhesive composition including a (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate groups and aromatic groups.
In another embodiment, the present invention provides an optical member including the adhesive film of the present invention.
description.heading: Brief description of drawings
description.p: Fig. 1 is a sectional view of an optical member according to one embodiment of the present invention.
description.heading: Detailed description of the Invention
description.p: In one aspect of the present invention, an adhesive composition may include a (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate groups and aromatic groups.

As used herein, the term "substituted" in "substituted or unsubstituted" means that a hydrogen atom is substituted with a C1-C10 alkyl group, a C3-C10 cycloalkyl group, a C6-C20 aryl group, a halogen, a hydroxylic group, or a C1-C10 alkoxy group.

heading.u: (Meth)acrylate copolymer carbonate groups and an aromatic groups

description.p: The copolymer may serve as a binder for an adhesive film. The copolymer may be cured together with photocurable monomers, and form a matrix of an adhesive film when the adhesive film is prepared from the adhesive composition.

Since the copolymer contains both an aromatic group and a carbonate group (-O-C(=O)-O-), the copolymer may have an index of refraction of ≥ 1.50 to ≤ 1.60. The copolymer can improve outdoor visibility of the adhesive film due to very high index of refraction, which is very similar to that of materials to which the adhesive film formed of the adhesive composition will be attached, for example, an ITO film of a touch panel.

The copolymer may have a dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0, preferably from ≥ 2.0 to ≤ 3.0, at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz. The copolymer may have a low dielectric constant by being prepared from a carbonate polyol having a low dielectric constant. As a result, an adhesive film prepared from an adhesive composition containing the copolymer has a lower dielectric constant than adhesive films in the art (for example, touch film). As a result, the adhesive film can be reduced in capacitance upon touch and can prevent signal delay, thereby enhancing sensitivity.
The copolymer may have a weight average molecular weight from ≥ 5,000 g/mol to ≤ 100,000 g/mol. Within this range, the copolymer can function effectively as an adhesive resin.
The copolymer may have a glass transition temperature (Tg) from ≥ -80°C to ≤ 0°C. Within this range, the copolymer can function as an effective adhesive resin.
The copolymer may include aromatic group, carbonate group, and (meth)acrylate group.
In the above, the "alkylene group" may be linear or branched.
In the above, '(CH2)n', '(CH2)m' or '(CH2)p' may be linear or branched.
Preferably, X1, X2, and X3 are a substituted or unsubstituted C1-C5 alkoxy group.
Preferably, a is an integer from 1 to 100, more preferably an integer from 1 to 50, still more preferably an integer from 1 to 10.
Preferably, A1 and A2 are a substituted or unsubstituted C6-C20 arylene group, more preferably a substituted or unsubstituted C6-C10 arylene group.
Preferably, D is a single bond, or a substituted or unsubstituted linear or branched C1-C5 alkylene group.

The copolymer may be a non-halogen copolymer. The copolymer does not include a halogen including fluorine, chlorine, iodine, or bromine. As a result, the copolymer is environmentally friendly and has an effect of preventing corrosion of electronic devices.

The copolymer may be prepared by a typical method. For example, the copolymer may be prepared by reacting a polyol containing an aromatic group and a carbonate group with a compound containing a (meth)acrylate group.

The polyol containing an aromatic group and a carbonate group is not particularly limited so long as the polyol has a low dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0 at 1,000 Hz, and an index of refraction of ≤ 1.50 due to the presence of at least one aromatic group. For example, the polyol may be a polycarbonate diol including units represented by Formula 5:
wherein q is an integer from 1 to 250.

The compound containing a (meth)acrylate group is not particularly limited so long as the compound includes a (meth)acrylate group and a functional group (for example, isocyanate group) capable of reacting with the polyol. For example, the (meth)acrylate group-containing compound may be (meth)acryloyloxyalkyl isocyanate.

The copolymer may be prepared by polymerizing a polyol containing an aromatic group and a carbonate group with a compound containing a (meth)acrylate group at 30°C to 60°C for ≥ 30 seconds to ≤ 24 hours. The polymerization may be performed by mass polymerization, emulsion polymerization, suspension polymerization, and the like.

The polymerization may be performed in the absence of a catalyst or in the presence of a catalyst. The catalyst may be, for example, at least one selected from the group consisting of dibutyltin dilaurate (DBTDL), triethylene diamine (TEDA), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane, without being limited thereto. The catalyst may be used in an amount of ≥ 0.05 parts by weight to ≤ 2 parts by weight based on 100 parts by weight of the polyol.

In addition, the copolymer may be prepared by polymerizing a polyol containing an aromatic group and a carbonate group, a compound containing a (meth)acrylate group, and a compound containing a silane group.

The compound containing a silane group is not particularly limited so long as the compound contains a silane group (-SiX1X2X3, wherein X1, X2 and X3 are the same or different, and each independently are a substituted or unsubstituted C1-C10 alkyl group, a substituted or unsubstituted C1-C10 alkoxy group, or a substituted or unsubstituted C6-C20 aryl group) and a functional group readily reactive with the polyol (for example, isocyanate group). For example, the compound may be isocyanate alkyl trialkoxysilane. In isocyanate alkyl trialkoxysilane, the alkyl group may be a C1-C10 alkyl group and the alkoxy group is a C1-C10 alkoxy group. Thus the copolymer may comprise carbonate groups, aromatic groups and silan group.

The copolymer may be present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 65 wt%, preferably ≥ 5 wt% to ≤ 50 wt%, more preferably ≥ 10 wt% to ≤ 30 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the copolymer can have enhanced sensitivity.
The adhesive composition may include a photocurable monomer, an initiator and a crosslinking agent, in addition to the (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate group and an aromatic group.

The photocurable monomer may include a non-aromatic photocurable monomer containing a vinyl group or a (meth)acrylate group without containing an aromatic group, a non-carbonate photocurable monomer containing a vinyl group or a (meth)acrylate group without containing carbonate group, or a combination thereof.

Examples of the photocurable monomer may include vinyl monomers containing hydroxyl group, vinyl monomers containing alkyl group, vinyl monomers containing alicyclic group, (meth)acrylic monomers containing hetero-alicyclic group, vinyl monomers containing carboxylic acid group, vinyl monomers containing silane group, and the like. Preferably, the photocurable monomer may include a vinyl monomer containing alkyl group, a vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group, a vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group and a (meth)acrylic monomer containing hetero-alicyclic group.

The photocurable monomer may be present in an amount of ≥ 15 wt% to ≤ 90 wt%, preferably ≥ 40 wt% to ≤ 90 wt%, in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range of the photocurable monomer, the composition can function as adhesives.

Examples of the vinyl monomer containing alkyl group may include (meth)acrylic esters having C1-C20 linear or branched alkyl groups. For example, the alkyl group-containing vinyl monomer may include at least one selected from the group consisting of methyl (meth)acrylate, ethyl (meth)acrylate, propyl (meth)acrylate, n-butyl (meth)acrylate, t-butyl (meth)acrylate, iso-butyl (meth)acrylate, pentyl (meth)acrylate, hexyl (meth)acrylate, heptyl (meth)acrylate, ethylhexyl (meth)acrylate, octyl (meth)acrylate, isooctyl (meth)acrylate, nonyl (meth)acrylate, decyl (meth)acrylate, and dodecyl (meth)acrylate, without being limited thereto. The vinyl monomer containing alkyl group may be used alone or in combination of two or more thereof.
The vinyl monomer containing alkyl group may be present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 75 wt%, preferably ≥ 50 wt% to ≤ 65 wt%, in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content.

The vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group is not particularly limited so long as the vinyl monomer contains a hydroxyl group and a carbon-carbon double bond. The vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group may contain at least one hydroxyl group. The hydroxyl group may be present at a terminal or inside of the monomer. The vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group may be a (meth)acrylic ester containing a hydroxyl group and a C1-C20 alkyl group. Examples of the vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group may include 2-hydroxyethyl (meth)acrylate, 4-hydroxybutyl (meth)acrylate, 2-hydroxypropyl (meth)acrylate, 2-hydroxybutyl (meth)acrylate, 6-hydroxyhexyl (meth)acrylate, 1,4-cyclohexane dimethanol mono(meth)acrylate, 1-chloro-2-hydroxypropyl (meth)acrylate, diethylene glycol mono(meth)acrylate, 1,6-hexanediol mono(meth)acrylate, pentaerythritol tri(meth)acrylate, dipentaerythritol penta(meth)acrylate, neopentylglycol mono(meth)acrylate, trimethylolpropane di(meth)acrylate, trimethylolethane di(meth)acrylate, 2-hydroxy-3-phenyloxypropyl (meth)acrylate, 4-hydroxycyclohexyl (meth)acrylate, 2-hydroxy-3-phenyloxy (meth)acrylate, 4-hydroxycyclopentyl (meth)acrylate, and cyclohexane dimethanol mono(meth)acrylate, without being limited thereto. The vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group may be used alone or in combination of two or more thereof.
The vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group may be present in an amount of > 1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, preferably ≥ 2 wt% to ≤ 9 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content.

Examples of the vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group may include (meth)acrylic esters containing a C4-C20 monocyclic or polycyclic alicyclic ring, preferably (meth)acrylic esters containing a C6-C20 monocyclic or polycyclic alicyclic ring. Examples of the vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group may include isobornyl (meth)acrylate, cyclohexyl (meth)acrylate, cyclopentyl (meth)acrylate, and the like. The vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group may be present in an amount of ≥ 5 wt% to ≤ 20 wt%, preferably ≥ 6 wt% to ≤ 18 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the composition may have improved durability.

Examples of the (meth)acrylic monomer containing hetero-alicyclic group may include (meth)acrylic monomer containing monocyclic C4-C6 hetero-alicyclic group containing nitrogen, oxygen or sulfur. Examples of the monomer may include (meth)acryloyl morpholine, and the like. The (meth)acrylic monomer containing hetero-alicyclic group may be present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, preferably ≥ 1wt% to ≤ 8 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the adhesive composition may exhibit improved adhesion to glass substrates.

Examples of the vinyl monomer containing carboxylic acid group may include at least one selected from the group consisting of β-carboxyethyl (meth)acrylate, (meth)acrylic acid, itaconic acid, maleic acid, fumaric acid, vinyl acetic acid, without being limited thereto. The vinyl monomer containing carboxylic acid group may be present in an amount of ≥ 0 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, preferably ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the adhesive composition can improve adhesion of optical adhesives.

The initiator may be a photoinitiator. The photoinitiator is activated by UV light or an electron beam, thus forming free radicals in a carbon-carbon double bond of an adhesive film, causing radical reaction.

Examples of the initiator may include acetophenone compounds, benzylketal type compounds or mixtures thereof, without being limited thereto. Preferably, examples of the acetophenone compound include 2,2-dimethoxy-2-phenylacetophenone, 2,2'-diethoxy acetophenone, 2,2'-dibutoxy acetophenone, 2-hydroxy-2-methyl propiophenone, p-t-butyl trichloro acetophenone, p-t-butyl dichloro acetophenone, 4-chloro acetophenone, 2,2'-dichloro-4-phenoxy acetophenone, 2-methyl-1-(4-(methylthio)phenyl)-2-morpholino propane-1-on, 2-benzyl-2-dimethyl amino-1-(4-morpholino phenyl)-butane-1-on, and mixtures thereof.

The initiator may be present in an amount of ≥ 0.1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, preferably ≥ 0.1 wt% to ≤ 5 wt% in an adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the composition can be completely cured when used as an adhesive film.
As the crosslinking agent, a multifunctional (meth)acrylate that is curable via electromagnetic irradiation may be used.

Examples of the crosslinking agent may include bifunctional (meth)acrylates, such as 1,4-butanediol di(meth)acrylate, 1,6-hexanediol di(meth)acrylate, neopentylglycol di(meth)acrylate, polyethyleneglycol di(meth)acrylate, neopentylglycol adipate di(meth)acrylate, dicyclopentanyl di(meth)acrylate, caprolactone modified dicyclopentenyl di(meth)acrylate, ethylene oxide modified di(meth)acrylate, di(meth)acryloxy ethyl isocyanurate, allylated cyclohexyl di(meth)acrylate, tricyclodecane dimethanol di(meth)acrylate, dimethylol dicyclopentane di(meth)acrylate, ethylene oxide modified hexahydrophthalic acid di(meth)acrylate, neopentylglycol modified trimethylpropane di(meth)acrylate, adamantane di(meth)acrylate or 9,9-bis[4-(2-(meth)acryloyloxyethoxy)phenyl]fluorene, and the like; trifunctional (meth)acrylates, such as trimethylolpropane tri(meth)acrylate, dipentaerythritol tri(meth)acrylate, propionic acid modified dipentaerythritol tri(meth)acrylate, pentaerythritol tri(meth)acrylate, propylene oxide modified trimethylolpropane tri(meth)acrylate, trifunctional urethane (meth)acrylate, tris(meth)acryloxyethyl isocyanurate, and the like; tetrafunctional (meth)acrylates, such as diglycerin tetra(meth)acrylate, pentaerythritol tetra(meth)acrylate, and the like; pentafunctional (meth)acrylates, such as dipentaerythritol penta(meth)acrylate, and the like; and hexafunctional (meth)acrylates, such as dipentaerythritol hexa(meth)acrylate, caprolactone modified dipentaerythritol hexa(meth)acrylate, and urethane hexa(meth)acrylate (e.g., reaction products of an isocyanate monomer and trimethylolpropane tri(meth)acrylate), without being limited thereto. The crosslinking agent may be used alone or in combination of two or more thereof.
As the crosslinking agent, multifunctional (meth)acrylates of C2-C20 multivalent alcohols may be used.
In addition, typical isocyanate, epoxy, aziridine, melamine, amine, imide, carbodiimide and amide crosslinking agents, or mixtures thereof may also be used.

The crosslinking agent may be present in an amount of ≥ 0.01 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, preferably ≥ 0.01 wt% to ≤ 5 wt% in the adhesive composition in terms of solid content. Within this range, the composition may have improved solvent resistance and degree of film crosslinking upon UV reaction, thereby providing improved durability.

The crosslinking agent may be present in an amount of ≥ 0.01 parts by weight to ≤ 50 parts by weight, preferably ≥ 0.01 parts by weight to ≤ 5 parts by weight, based on 100 parts by weight of the copolymer.

The adhesive composition may further include typical additives, for example, silane coupling agents, curing accelerators, an ionic liquid, lithium salt, inorganic fillers, softeners, antioxidants, anti-aging agents, stabilizers, tackifier resins, reforming resins such as polyol resins, phenolic resins, acrylic resins, polyester resins, polyolefin resins, epoxy resins, epoxylated polybutadiene resins, and the like, leveling agents, antifoaming agents, plasticizers, dyes, pigments such as coloring and extender pigments, treatment agents, UV blocking agents, fluorescent whitening agents, dispersants, heat stabilizers, light stabilizers, UV absorbers, antistatic agents, lubricants, and solvents, as needed. The additives may be present in an amount of ≥ 0.01 parts by weight to ≤ 5 parts by weight, preferably ≥ 0.03 parts by weight to ≤ 3 parts by weight, more preferably ≥ 0.05 parts by weight to ≤ 2 parts by weight, based on 100 parts by weight of the copolymer.

The adhesive composition may be prepared as follows. The copolymer, photocurable monomer, and initiator are mixed and partially polymerized by UV irradiation to obtain a viscous liquid. To this liquid, the crosslinking agent, initiator and then additional additives are added to prepare an adhesive composition.

Another aspect of the present invention provides an adhesive film having a dielectric constant variation of ≤ 30%, as expressed by Equation 1: Dielectric constant variation%=A-BA⁢X100,
wherein A is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz, and B is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 106 Hz.

The dielectric constant variation is preferably ≥ 10% to ≤ 30%, more preferably > 25% to ≤ 30%. The adhesive film exhibits lower dielectric constant variation than existing adhesive films, particularly touch films. As a result, the adhesive film can be reduced in capacitance upon touch and can prevent signal delay, thereby enhancing sensitivity.

A further aspect of the present invention provides an adhesive film having an average dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0 at 103Hz to 106 Hz and a resistance variation (△R) of ≤ 2%, as expressed by Equations 2 and 3, respectively. Average Dielectric constant=Emax+Emin2,
wherein Emax is a maximum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz, and Emin is a minimum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz. ΔR=P2-P1P1X100,
wherein P1 is an initial resistance (unit: Ω) measured on a sample with electrodes formed at both ends of the adhesive film, and P2 is resistance (unit: Ω) of the sample after storage at 60°C/90% RH for 240 hours.
In some embodiments, the adhesive film may have an average dielectric constant of ≥ 2.0 to ≤ 3.0 and a resistance variation of ≥ 1.0% to ≤ 2.0%.

When the average dielectric constant of the adhesive film is ≤ 3.0 and the resistance variation thereof is ≤ 2.0%, the adhesive film can be reduced in capacitance upon touch and can prevent signal delay, thereby enhancing sensitivity.

The adhesive film has an index of refraction of ≥ 1.48, preferably from ≥ 1.48 to ≤ 1.50. The adhesive film may have an index of refraction very similar to that of a transparent window glass (an index of refraction: 1.50), thus improving outdoor readability.
The adhesive film may have an acid value of 0 mg KOH/g, which prevents variation in resistance upon attaching the adhesive film to a transparent conductive film.
The adhesive film may be prepared from the adhesive composition.
The adhesive film according to the invention may be formed by curing the adhesive composition. For example, the adhesive composition is coated to a release film

(for example, polyester comprising polyethylene terephthalate film) and UV-cured. In one embodiment, UV curing may be carried out at ≤ 50 mW for 20 seconds to 240 seconds. Curing may be carried out in an anoxic environment.
Although there is no particular restriction as to coating thickness, the adhesive composition may be coated to thickness from ≥ 50 µm to ≤ 2 mm, for example, from > 150 µm to ≤ 1.5 mm.

Although the thickness of the adhesive film (thickness except release film thickness) is not particularly limited, the adhesive film may have a thickness of ≥ 10 µm to ≤ 1 mm, for example, ≥ 50 µm to ≤ 1.5 mm.
A further aspect of the present invention provides an optical member.

The optical member may include an optical film, and the adhesive film attached to at least one side of the optical film. The optical film may be a a polarizing plate, a color filter, a retardation film, an oval polarizing film, a reflective film, an anti-reflection film, a compensation film, a brightness enhancement film, an alignment film, a light diffusion film, an anti-glass scattering film, a surface protective film, a plastic LCD substrate, a glass substrate such as a window glass, a transparent conductive film such as an ITO film, and the like. The optical film can be easily manufactured by a person skilled in the art using a typical method known in the art.

For example, a touchpad is attached to a window or optical film using the adhesive film, thereby forming a touch panel. Alternatively, the adhesive film may be applied to a general polarizing film by a conventional method. In one embodiment, the optical member may include a capacitive touch panel and a capacitive-type mobile phone.

Fig. 1 is a sectional view of an optical member according to one embodiment. Referring to Fig. 1, the optical member may include an optical film (200); and an adhesive film (110) formed on the optical film (200).

Next, the present invention will be explained in more detail with reference to some examples and comparative examples. These examples are provided for illustration only and are not to be in any way construed as limiting the present invention.

heading.b: Preparative Example 1: (Meth)acrylate copolymer 1 containing carbonate groups and aromatic groups

description.p:
To a four-neck 2L flask, 90 g of a carbonate polyol containing an aromatic group was added and heated to 60°C. Then, 0.5 g of dibutyltin dilaurate diluted in toluene in a ratio of 10% was added to the flask. The resultant was cooled to 50°C and then 6 g of 2-methacryloylchloride and 6 g of 2-methacryloyloxyethyl isocyanate (MOI) were added thereto. The resultant was maintained at 50°C for seven hours. After identifying through IR that NCO groups of MOI were not observed, the resultant was cooled to 40°C. A (meth)acrylate polymer containing carbonate groups and aromatic groups represented by Formula 1A was prepared:
wherein a is 4.
description.heading: Preparative Example 2: (Meth)acrylate copolymer 2 containing carbonate groups and aromatic groups
description.p:
To a four-neck 2L flask, 90 g of a carbonate polyol containing an aromatic group was added and heated to 60°C. Then, 0.5 g of dibutyltin dilaurate diluted in toluene in a ratio of 10% was added to the flask. 11 g of 3-isocyanatepropyl triethoxysilane was added and the temperature was maintained at 60°C for 3 hours. After identifying through IR that NCO groups of MOI were not observed, the resultant was cooled to 50°C, and then 6 g of 2-methacryloyloxyethyl isocyanate (MOI) was added. The resultant was maintained at 50°C for 7 hours. After identifying through IR that NCO groups of MOI were not observed, the resultant was cooled to 40°C. A (meth)acrylate copolymer containing carbonate groups and aromatic groups and a silane group represented by Formula 1B was prepared:
wherein a is 4.

Details of components used in Examples and Comparative Examples are as follows:
(A) (Meth)acrylate copolymer containing carbonate groups and aromatic groups: (A1) Copolymer prepared in Preparative Example 1, (A2) Copolymer prepared in Preparative Example 2
(B) Photocurable monomer: (B1) ethylhexylacrylate (EHA), (B2) isobornyl acrylate (IBOA), (B3) 2-hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA), (B4) acryloyl morpholine (ACMO)
(C) Initiator: Irgacure M651 (2,2-dimethoxy-2-phenylacetophenone) (Ciba Japan K.A.)
(D) Crosslinking agent: 1,6-hexanediol diacrylate (HDDA)

Viscous liquids were obtained by mixing (A), (B), in amounts as listed in Table 1, and 0.04 parts by weight of (C) initiator in a glass container, followed by replacing dissolved oxygen with nitrogen gas, and polymerizing the mixture by irradiation using a low pressure lamp for a few minutes. To the obtained composition, 0.26 parts by weight of the (C) initiator and the (D) crosslinking agent in amounts as listed in Table 1 were added and thoroughly mixed to prepare an adhesive composition.

The prepared adhesive composition was applied to a 50 µm thick polyester release film, followed by performing release treatment at a layer thickness of 100 µm In order to remove oxygen, which negatively affects polymerization, the release film was covered, and irradiated from two surfaces using a low-pressure lamp (Sylvania BL Lamp) for 3 minutes to obtain a transparent adhesive sheet. TABLE 1
Example 1Example 2Example 3Example 4Comparative Example 1

(A2)-151515-
(B)(B1)59595757.274
(B2)11.211.211.21311.2

The prepared adhesive sheets were evaluated as to the following physical properties. Results are shown in Table2.
(1) Resistance variation: Each of the adhesive sheets prepared in the examples and the comparative examples were attached to ITO and PET and electrodes were formed on opposite sides thereof using a silver paste, thereby preparing a sample. Initial resistance (P1, unit: Ω) of the sample was measured. The sample was left at 60°C/90%RH for 240 hours, followed by evaluation of resistance (P2, unit: Ω). Here, resistance was measured using portable test instrument for measuring resistance, voltage, and current (Checkman, Tae Kwang Electronics Co.). To calculate resistance variation (ΔR), the obtained resistances under the above-mentioned conditions were substituted into Equation 3.
(2) Durability: A PC film/ITO film/glass and a PET film were bonded and left at 60°C/90%RH for 500 hours, followed by observation with the naked eye to identify whether separation, peeling, or bubbles occurred on an adherend. Evaluation was performed as follows.
O: Good (no bubbles and no peeling)
X: Poor (large amount of bubbles or severe peeling)
(3) Optical properties: An adhesive composition was coated on a release PET film, followed by curing at 3000 mJ/cm2 to prepare a 200 µm thick adhesive film. After removing the release film, transmittance and yellow index of the 200 µm thick adhesive film were measured using a Lambda 950 (manufactured by Perkin Elmer) in the range of wavelength 400∼800 nm.

After removing the release film, the 200 µm thick adhesive film was evaluated using a hazemeter (NHD-200W). The adhesive film was subjected to aging for 30 minutes prior to the measurement, and the sample had a size of 5 cm x 5 cm x 200 µm (width x length x thickness). After opening the cover of the hazemeter, the sample was set in the hazemeter with sample texture directed in the mechanical direction (MD), and the optical properties of the sample were measured 3 times.
(4) Dielectric constant, dielectric constant variation and average dielectric constant: Dielectric constant of an adhesive film (width x length x thickness = 4 cm x 6 cm x 100 µm) was measured at 103 Hz to 106 Hz using an E5515E 8960 (Agilent). Dielectric constant variation and average dielectric constant were measured in accordance with Equations 1 and 2.
(5) Index of refraction: Index of refraction was measured according to ASTM D1218. An adhesive composition was coated onto a PET release film and cured at 3000 mJ/cm2 to prepare a 175 µm thick adhesive film. After removing the release film, an index of refraction of the 200 µm adhesive film was measured using an ABBE5 refractometer (Bellingham/Stanley Ltd.). TABLE 2

As shown in Table 2, the adhesive films according to the examples of the inventive exhibited low dielectric constant variation. However, since the adhesive films according to the examples of the inventive had high indexes of refraction, the adhesive films did not suffer from touch malfunction and could have improved outdoor readability. On the other hand, the adhesive films according to Comparative Example 1 wherein the copolymer of the invention was not used had high dielectric constant variation and a low index of refraction, thereby failing to achieve the advantageous effects of the invention.

Although some embodiments have been described herein, it will be apparent to those skilled in the art that these embodiments are given by way of illustration only, and that various modifications, changes, alterations, and equivalent embodiments can be made without departing from the spirit and scope of the invention. The scope of the invention should be limited only by the accompanying claims and equivalents thereof.

claim.claim-text: An adhesive composition comprising: a (meth)acrylate copolymer having carbonate groups and an aromatic groups.

The adhesive composition according to claim 1, wherein the (meth)acrylate copolymer has a dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0 at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz and an index of refraction of ≥ 1.50 to ≤ 1.60.
The adhesive composition according to claim 1 or 2, wherein the (meth)acrylate copolymer has a weight average molecular weight of ≥ 5,000 g/mol to ≤ 100,000g/mol.
The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 4, comprising: the (meth)acrylate copolymer, a photocurable monomer, an initiator and a crosslinking agent.

The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 5, comprising: ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 65 wt% of the (meth)acrylate copolymer, ≥ 15 wt% to ≤ 90 wt% of the photocurable monomer, ≥ 0.1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt% of the initiator, and ≥ 0.01 wt% to ≤ 10 wt% of the crosslinking agent.

The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 6, wherein the photocurable monomer includes a vinyl monomer containing alkyl group, a vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group, a vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group and a (meth)acrylic monomer containing hetero-alicyclic group.

The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 7, wherein the vinyl monomer containing alkyl group is present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 75 wt%, the vinyl monomer containing hydroxyl group is present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, the vinyl monomer containing alicyclic group is present in an amount of ≥ 5 wt% to ≤ 20 wt%, and the (meth)acrylic monomer containing hetero-alicyclic group is present in an amount of ≥ 1 wt% to ≤ 10 wt%, in the adhesive composition.
The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 8, further comprising: a silane coupling agent.

The adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 9, further comprising: curing accelerators, an ionic liquid, lithium salt, inorganic fillers, softeners, antioxidants, anti-aging agents, stabilizers, tackifier resins, reforming resins, leveling agents, antifoaming agents, plasticizers, dyes, pigments, treatment agents, UV blocking agents, fluorescent whitening agents, dispersants, heat stabilizers, light stabilizers, UV absorbers, anti-static agents, lubricants, or solvents.

An adhesive film having an index of refraction of ≥ 1.48 and a dielectric constant variation of ≤ 30%, as expressed by Equation 1: Dielectric constant variation%=A-BA⁢X100,
wherein A is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz, and B is the dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 106 Hz; and/or
the adhesive film having an average dielectric constant of ≤ 3.0 at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz and a resistance variation (△R) of ≤ 2%, as expressed by Equations 2 and 3,
respectively: Average Dielectric constant=Emax+Emin2,
wherein Emax is a maximum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz, and Emin is a minimum dielectric constant of the adhesive film measured at a frequency of 103 Hz to 106 Hz, ΔR=P2-P1P1X100,
wherein P1 is an initial resistance (unit: Ω) measured on a sample with electrodes formed at both ends of the adhesive film, and P2 is resistance (unit: Ω) of the sample after storage at 60°C/90%RH for 240 hours.
The adhesive film according to claim 11, comprising an adhesive composition according to claims 1 to 10.
An optical member comprising the adhesive film according to claims 11 or 12.
